DOC.HEAD: Drug Traffickers Slain in Colombia, Turf War Feared
DOC.TEXT: The slaying of a cocaine lord last week may have touched off a bloody war by mid-level traffickers fighting to take his place in the notorious Medellin cartel, police were quoted Friday as saying. The national police investigations chief, Col. Oscar Eduardo Pelaez, said Thursday six men were found dead at a south Bogota dump. At least four of the victims, who were found Wednesday, belonged to the slain cocaine boss' group, the official said. Four other bodies were found in a resort town late Thursday, and five men died in a Bogota prison earlier in the week in a turf fight between prisoners of rival drug organizations. Some officials had been predicting violence between rival cartel factions since police shot and killed Gonzalo Rodriguez Gacha in a Dec. 15 gunfight on the country's northern coast. Rodriguez Gacha, the Medellin cartel's No. 2 leader, died with his 17-year-old son, four bodyguards and another trafficker. Bogota's El Tiempo newspaper Friday quoted police sources as saying that Rodriguez Gacha's organization of about 2,000 men had been thrown into chaos by their leader's death. ``Some of them have given up their arms, others have fled, and others have returned to their normal activities,'' said an unidentified police official quoted by the paper. However, El Tiempo added that some officials fear that mid-level traffickers are trying to take control of the dead drug lord's operation and reorganize it. The six men whose bodies were found at the dump were apparently killed as a result of internal power struggles in the cartel, said Pelaez. He told reporters at a news conference the victims had been gagged and shot, and their bodies showed signs of torture. One of the bodies matched witnesses' descriptions of a man who drove a bus bomb into the secret police headquarters in Bogota on Dec. 6, Pelaez said. The bus, loaded with about 1,100 pounds of dynamite, exploded moments later, killing 63 people and injuring about 1,000. Gen. Miguel Maza Marquez, the secret police chief, had accused Rodriguez Gacha of ordering the attack with the No. 1 man in the Medellin cartel, Pablo Escobar. He remains at large. Police found four more bodies late Thursday along a road leading from the capital to the resort town of Melgar, 55 miles to the south. El Espectador newspaper, citing police sources, reported Friday that the deaths were the result of battles between feuding criminals groups. A police spokesman told The Associated Press by telephone that he could not say whether the victims had worked for Rodriguez Gacha. Five men died Tuesday when two bands of prisoners battled with knives at a Bogota jail. Police said Rodriguez Gacha's men attacked a group of prisoners of a rival group that had been fighting with the drug trafficker for control of emerald mines in central Colombia. The family of Rodriguez Gacha issued a statement to the news media Friday saying his ``battles, political ideals, and convictions had been buried with him.'' The statement, signed by two brothers of the trafficker, said the family had no ``dark desire for vengeance or retaliation'' and wanted peace for the country.
